contentrichtext.text: {{Infobox person | name = Albert Hamilton Gordon | birth_date = July 21, 1901 | birth_place = [[Scituate, Massachusetts]], USA | death_date = {{death date and age|2009|05|01|1901|07|21}} | death_place = [[New York, New York]], USA | occupation = Wall Street entrepreneur}} '''Albert Hamilton Gordon''' (July 21, 1901 – May 1, 2009),<ref name="Times obit">{{cite news|title=Albert Gordon, Who Rebuilt Kidder Peabody, Dies at 107|first=Douglas|last=Martin|date=May 1, 2009|accessdate=May 2, 2009|work=[[The New York Times]]|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2009/05/02/business/02gordon.html}}</ref> was a businessman who transformed the [[Wall Street]] firm of [[Kidder Peabody]]. He bought the firm in 1931 and remained its chairman until selling it to [[General Electric]] in 1986. He made cold calls to potential clients well into his 90s and continued to come to his office at [[Deltec Asset Management]] several times a week until he was over 100.<ref name="Times obit"/> During his life, he was well known for his physical fitness. He made it a habit to walk from downtown New York to Idlewild/JFK Airport, and was also known to walk to hotels rather than take a cab from the airport. He began running marathons in his 80s, exercised daily until his death, and would regularly play golf, without a golf cart, carrying his own clubs (although he usually made do with only a handful of clubs, rather than an entire bag). He later attributed his longevity to his dedication to physical fitness Past 100 years old he continued to serve as the chairman of the [[Anthony Trollope|Trollope Society]]<ref>[http://www.trollopeusa.org/tsociety/dinners.html Website of the Trollope Society]</ref> and as chairman of the Board of Trustees of the [[Roxbury Latin School]], having graduated from there in 1919 and served as a Trustee since 1940; among his [[Philanthropy|philanthropic]] activities were generous donations both to the School and to [[Harvard University]].<ref name="Times obit"/> Unknown to many as a bibliophile, Gordon donated the only surviving copy of John Eliot’s 1663 “Indian Bible” to Roxbury Latin School<ref>http://www.observer.com/2009/friendship-land-lost-content</ref> In his latest years Gordon was still actively involved in investments and was bearish on U.S. stocks prior to the [[Financial crisis of 2007–2010|Financial crisis of 2007-2010]].<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.bloomberg.com/apps/news?pid=newsarchive&sid=aEdasIztSWlc | work=Bloomberg | title=Gordon, Wall Street Icon at 105, Avoids U.S. Stocks (Update1) | date=August 30, 2006}}</ref> At the time of his death, he was the oldest living alumnus of [[The Roxbury Latin School]], [[Harvard College]] and [[Harvard Business School]].<ref>[http://www.news.harvard.edu/gazette/2007/06.14/09-oldest.html Harvard University Gazette Online]</ref> He was also a trustee of the [[New York Road Runners]] Club.<ref name="Times
